The Roman law regarded certain os a man's relations as having so strong a claim to succeed to his property, that it required him, ii he wished effec- tually to exclude them, to disinherit them in his will ; not, as we should, by simply not mentioning them at all, but by explicitly stating his desire that they should not be his heirs. Merely to pass them over, without either instituting them heirs or expressly disinheriting them, did not ex· clude them at all; it simply avoided the will, either in whole, or in part.
